Message.Title: HP Continues to Expand Its Android Arsenal
Message.Msg: Google it. Quoting: "As if there was any doubt left that Hewlett-Packard (NYSE: HPQ ) is sick of Wintel, the top PC vendor in the world has just announced a new device that further diversifies HP away from Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT ) and Intel. "The Slate 21 is an all-in-one desktop that runs Google (NASDAQ: GOOG ) Android 4.2.2 Jelly Bean and sports an NVIDIA (NASDAQ: NVDA ) Tegra 4 processor inside instead of the usual Wintel combination. The PC is a 21.5-inch touchscreen device that can even be used as an enormous tablet if one is so inclined. The news comes on the heels of HP unveiling its Slatebook x2 last month, an Android/Tegra-powered convertible laptop." ______________________________ Giving the lie to osso's repeated nonsense about Android going away.

Message.Title: Cramer said maybe MSFT Should by Netflix
Message.Msg: He say maybe Ballmer is listening. I do not think Mr. Ballmer needs his suggestion. Microsoft had a partnership starting with Microsoft Silverlight that was used for online Movie streaming. I found out last week that Nokia owns NSN and they allow Netflix movies to run without starting and stopping. Pretty important. Microsoft already has a partnership with Nokia and the new partnership in the works. Hopefully NSN is invited and then Netflix is very dependent on Microsoft and the take out will be cheaper by the Microsoft Entertainment Division.

Topic.Title: Is MSFT & Oracle partnership prelude to a mega merger?

Message.Msg: Microsoft is using Nokia's IP & Patents for the HERE maps integration. So many of Oracles customers need map integration that actually works. This one does. So with Microsoft Windows 8, Oracles customers can get a complete integration from Oracle even though Microsoft is providing the service. Microsoft offers Service to large corporations, Governments & Military. The cloud security is a big issue. Oracle + Microsoft + Nokia is a complete solution not multiple solutions. Mobile is now a mandatory part of IT services. So A Gov. can order phones, laptops, desktops, vehicle navigation all on the same OS and all uploading and syncing to the same Secure Cloud. Remember all Microsoft phones, etc are safe. A system admin. can wipe a Windows 8 phone remotely. The ability to see where all mobile phones are on a map from Nokia is an extremely nice extra. Pair that with the fact that Xbox One allows Skype HD voice conferencing that business & anyone can use is a game changer. That saves vast amount of monies compared to Cisco. It is a complete solution. The other competitor complete solutions were fragmented, unsafe and costly. Welcome to the Microsoft complete solution.

Topic.Title: Ctr-Alt-Del on the touchscreen ?

Message.Msg: Depends on machine. If you are in a form field that allows typing swipe up from bottom center of screen and keyboard will appear. If you are trying to kill all programs and exit. Than you can create a link on the desktop and put this line in as the target: C:\Windows\System32\shutdown.exe -s -t 00 So however you have your device set up or if there is a key, button or function you can set up with the instruction above it will shut down the machine.

Topic.Title: Ctr-Alt-Del on the touchscreen ?

Message.Msg: No, for what you are talking about is called the task manager. I just tried it on a Windows 8 machine. It is same as ever. The touchscreen notebooks have keypads. You just do the same thing ctr alt del and it brings up task mgr, switch user, sign off etc. First of all, I have so many Windows 8 devices I cannot keep track. I have never had one single freeze ever. NOT ONE SINGLE FREEZE ON WINDOWS 8. Windows Key get's you out of anything. Windows ME way back in the 90's might freeze. I have not had any. You can configure a function key to bring the task bar up but you are one of the riff raff trying to bash in a problem from the 90's. Windows 8 is great. Immediate boot and not freezes. Get over it, Windows 8 is great. I am loving it. Yea buuuuddddeeeeeee! b o o o y a a ah!

Message.Title: An Operating System for the Commercial Drone Era
Message.Msg: Google it. Quoting: "At Boeing, Jonathan Downey once worked on the development of the A160 Hummingbird, an unmanned helicopter used by the U.S. military. "Now drones are just starting to launch into nonmilitary markets, and Downey’s startup, Airware, hopes to build a standard operating system to speed their adoption. He compares his company’s platform to DOS, the Microsoft software that helped propel the early era of personal computing." ... "Downey, who is himself a commercial pilot, says Airware is aiming to straddle today’s hobbyist and military applications. " “People would hate to see 100 different drones flying overhead, with 100 different hardware platforms and 100 different software platforms running on those drones,” he says. “Some degree of standardization is in everyone’s best interests.” "Airware’s Linux-based autopilot, at a cost of $4,000 to $7,000, is meant to make it easy to manufacture drones that could easily be customized by customers or third-party developers who want to build apps or integrate new kinds of sensors. "Mary Cummings, director of MIT’s Humans and Automation Lab, who knew Downey when he entered drone competitions as an MIT student, says such a system is “sorely needed” because most drone-flying technologies are proprietary, closed systems. If Airware pulls off its goal to become a widespread platform, she says, its architecture could boost the emerging commercial industry. While huge companies such as Lockheed Martin have said they are working on similar projects, she says, results have been slow to materialize."
